channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: US Based, Modern Perl Developer Role - 100% remote!
item.description: Our client is looking for a Perl programmer who wants to tame the job jungle for employers and employees through their candidate sourcing and data management products. TThe perfect candidate has strong experience with Modern Perl, is located within the US and is keen for a remote role! Is that you?

item.title: The Future is Now! Perl Role in Malaysia
item.description: If you’re a Perl programmer with a passion for finance, this role may be the one for you. Our client is a financial company whose stunning growth over the last twenty years shows that they belong in the city of the future. They’ve built a company with an international presence on that idea, and business is booming.

item.title: That’s a Big Sandbox! Perl role in London
item.description: The organization whose servers handle a jaw-dropping 80% of the UK’s job ads is looking for a few good humans, and you could be one of them! The client is interested in anyone with experience building web apps in Perl, using one of the major Perl frameworks.

item.title: Cooking Up Something Good. Perl role in London
item.description: With a knack for tailoring content to a variety of site aesthetics, our client sets a banquet of advertising delights for over 349 million consumers around the world. If your mouth is watering at the thought of joining this dynamic team and you’re a senior Perl programmer with a solid understanding of Go programming languages, they just might set a place for you at the table.

item.title: Not All Heroes Wear Capes. Perl in Vienna
item.description: Very well-known Austrian e-commerce brand looking for a heroic Perl programmer to develop and deliver quality content and all the info users need to find their gadgets for the right price. Client is willing to consider all candidates with strong Perl, but they make heavy use of PostgreSQL, Elasticsearch, and Modern Perl.

item.title: The Perl and Raku Conference in the Cloud 2021
item.description: Online 8-10 June 2021.

item.title: Silicon Valley Perl - Git Hooks(Client-side)
item.description: Thursday, May 22, 2021

item.description: May 13th, 2021 06:00 PM Central Time (US and Canada)

item.description: Wednesday, May 12, 2021

item.description: Wednesday, May 5, 2021; 07:00 PM Eastern Time (US and Canada)

item.title: NICEPERL's lists
item.description:
Great modules released last week;
MetaCPAN weekly report;
StackOverflow Perl report.

Live Video - Valid Phone Numbers by Mohammad Anwar

DevOps work - setting up CI and Docker for the course management project
s3path the Python File-System/Path like interface for AWS S3
item.description: Lior Mizrahi, the author of the package introduces it and then we fix a bug.

item.title: Setting up ELK using Rexify
item.description: Another episode of the 'Automation with Rex' series in which we follow the Ansible playbook to set up Elasticsearch and Nginx on CentOS.

item.title: Course Management Application in Mojolicious - part 5
item.description: The 5th part in which we set up redirection, refactored the tests, and started to test the upload file phase.

item.title: Weekly Challenge 110
item.description: Cool use of map and logical-defined-or; thanks for sharing the magic.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 110: Transpose Numbers
item.description: I noticed Roger not using \d in the regex, instead using [0-9]. I remember reading somewhere it is the preferred choice.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 110: Mangling Text File
item.description: Luca shared some cool Raku magic dealing with regex. Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 110
item.description: Luis shared multiple solutions to the Transpose File task. Simply loved it. Thanks.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 110: Valid Phone Numbers and Transposed File
item.description: Laurent has been consistently sharing solutions in more than just Perl and Raku. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #110
item.description: I loved the discussion about memory usage for the Transpose File task. It is always a pleasure to read code showing the memory utilisation. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge: Week 110
item.description: Jaldhar shared a mix of Perl and Raku magics. Cool use. Thanks.

item.title: PWC110 - Transpose File
item.description: Flavio shared a special use of open(). Thanks for sharing the knowledge.

item.title: PWC110 - Valid Phone Numbers
item.description: Flavio never misses the opportunity to surprise us. Thanks for the short and sweet discussion on the subject.

item.title: Hanging On The Telephone: Perl Weekly Challenge #110
item.description: Dave presented us some information background about Phone Numbers. Also shared s special use of Text::CSV. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Flip Me Your Digits, Baby
item.description: Cool use of regex, something I never used before. Thanks Colin.

item.title: CY's Take on PWC#110
item.description: I loved his frank admission the checking other contributions and building a different solution is not an easy job. Kudo to your efforts.

item.title: Validly Transposed Raku and Perl
item.description: Arne used a special trick to deal with the Valid Phone Numbers task by only looking at the first 4 characters.

item.title: Challenge 110
item.description: Thanks for introducing Raku grammars and welcome back after the short break.

item.title: Checking Phone Numbers and Transposing Tabular Data the Hard Way: The Weekly Challenge 110
item.description: Adam never hesitates to try a unique tool. This week he used Parse::Yapp grammar. Thanks for sharing.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 110: Transpose File
item.description: Abigail's blog post is full of magical code. I loved the one-liner solution in Perl.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 110: Valid Phone Numbers
item.description: I have learnt something new today - chained regexes in Perl. Thanks Abigail for sharing.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 110
item.description: Please check out these Raku solutions by Aaron Smith.

item.title: Perl Review - Perl Weekly Challenge - 108
item.description: Perl Solutions Review by Colin Crain.

item.title: RECAP - The Weekly Challenge - 110
item.description: Enjoy a quick recap of last week's contributions from Team PWC dealing with the "Valid Phone Numbers" and "Transpose File" tasks in Perl and Raku. You will find plenty of solutions to keep you busy.

item.title: The Weekly Challenge - 111
item.description: Welcome to a new week with a couple of fun tasks "Search Matrix" and "Ordered Letters". If you are new to the weekly challenge then why not join us and have fun every week. For more information, please read the FAQ.

item.title: Scalar::Type
item.description: David released a complete new distribution to figure out what type a scalar is.

item.title: Perl test coverage when you don’t have a Makefile
item.description: Mark trying to resolve a test coverage issue in this blog post.

item.title: Creating REST APIs with Perl, Mojolicious and OpenAPI
item.description: Gaurav has been blogging regularly to create a REST API using Mojolicious and OpenAPI. Always fun to read his blog posts.

item.title: EV charge pricing per State in US
item.description: Charlie's attempt to solve a practical problem using Perl. A very cool attempt.

item.title: Perl tops coding salary rankings
item.description: Mark shared a discussion about Perl salary rankings.

item.title: There's no such thing as "The Perl Community"
item.description: Neil's take on what actually is community. He took pains to explain the term in great detail.

item.title: Heail - head and tail together
item.description: Flavio once again created a very handy tool, Heail, in this blog post.

item.title: JSONify a string
item.description: Flavio continued with his daily blogging series and presents how to stringify CSS as JSON.

item.title: Downloading and Installing Perl in 2021
item.description: Mark continued his blogging series and presented the basics of installing Perl on various platforms.

item.title: Installing wxPerl for Strawberry Perl v5.32.0, or: Future of wxPerl?
item.description: John shares his experience dealing with wxPerl.

item.title: Community Affairs Team Transparency Report Update
item.description: The CAT would like to make some corrections, as well as address some of the comments and questions we received on the initial transparency report.

item.title: #510 - The Perl Community?
item.description:
Hi there

I am not sure if you have read the recent blog post by Neil Bowers. I have read it multiple times to understand the subject of the post. I must admit, I had never read such an in depth analysis of the term "Community". As my vocabulary is rather limited, I found it very interesting to read such a long blog post. To me, community is group of like-minded people. When I attended my first London Perl Workshop, I immediately felt part of the community. The organiser and everybody was so accommodating and friendly. It made me come again the following year and I became addicted to it afterwards. I always looked up to the big names of the community everytime I needed some inspiration. Take a look at the past recipients of the White Camel Award, you can get some idea of who's who in the community. Unfortunately it hasn't been awarded since 2018 for some reason that I am not aware of. I miss the community spirit of attending Perl Conferences. You can never experience that feeling unless you attend one. I hope and wish we get back to attending conferences. Although there has been virtual events in recent times, it can't replace real events in my humble opinion. I must give credit to everyone who is keeping the community spirit alive.

Today is a bank holiday in the UK, so all the British readers of the newsletter, enjoy your break with the newsletter. Rest of the world, start your week with weekly doses of Perl news. Stay safe and healthy.
